Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating Decadal Climate Predictability and Climate Impacts (IDCPI) on the Western United States
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports a team of researchers in a major research thrust in decadal climate prediction entitled "Investigating Decadal Climate Predictability and Climate Impacts (IDCPI) on the Western US." The IDCPI is an interdisciplinary effort to use instrumental records of climate and paleoclimate data to assess the skill level of Earth System Models (EaSM) to forecast decadal climate variability.

Generally, the research team will focus on the region of the western Unites States because both historic and prehistoric records document recurrent decadal-scale hydroclimate variability, including repeated drought, which has been attributed to Sea Surface Temperature (SST) anomalies.

Specifically, the team will use models, in combination with an isotope "fingerprinting" methodology, to: 1) assess the ability of Earth System models (global and regional models) to accurately simulate the atmospheric response to SST forcing; 2) retrospectively investigate whether models can predict drought in advance and estimate how long the events will persist; 3) assess whether a future drought in the western U.S. is currently predictable with existing models; and 4) develop future hydrologic predictions with uncertainty estimates for the western U.S. where models exhibit skill.

This project has the potential to improve the reliability of regional climate predictions in the southwest Unites States. In doing so, the research would be of importance to resource managers and policy makers. The project also provides a unique cohort approach to the training and mentoring of post doctoral scholars associated with the collaborating institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to test the hypothesis that decadal variations in hydroclimate and the occurrence of extreme events such as drought in the Western US is attributable to recurrent sea surface temperature anomalies. We further hypothesized that the hydroclimate trajectory for the 21st century in this region has already been affected by anthropogenic forcings that has reduced ocean and atmospheric temperature gradients.

We found that decadal hydroclimate variability over western North America is affected by the large-scale sea-surface temperature gradient between tropical Atlantic and Pacific. Subtle changes to this gradient have an important effect on precipitation amount, soil moisture variability and wild fire frequency across the southwestern United States. The inter-basinal temperature gradient has influenced the recent trend in equatorial Pacific trade wind strength, accelerated sea level rise in the Western tropical Pacific and to the Global Warming Hiatus. We also found that the Atlantic/Pacific sea surface temperature gradient and corresponding sea level pressure anomalies have a potential predictability of up to 3 years.

Using NCAR’s Community Earth System model and global ocean temperature and salinity data assimilation, a new multi-year climate prediction system was developed and tested by our group. The prediction model successfully hindcasted past hydroclimate anomalies in the Southwestern US with up to 3 years lead time. When initialized in 2015, our model predicted a weakening of drought in California for the water year 2015, in agreement with the observations and the expected 2015/2016 El Niño impact.

The interaction between strong El Niño events and the seasonal cycle can be used to predict wind, sea level pressure, precipitation and ocean circulation and sea level anomalies. A new mathematical framework to describe these interactions in terms of what we call: “Combination Modes” was developed.

Using a combination of paleo-proxy records we developed a new reconstruction of the variance of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon, for the past 600 years. According to the statistical analysis, the last 40 years in ENSO variance exceeded any previous period.

Our findings also show that the previous studies have misinterpreted isotope-based proxies because the variables responsible for the isotopic composition of atmospheric moisture are non-uniform across land surfaces. These findings are important for future paleoclimate. For example, the stable isotope composition of atmospheric moisture varies with latitude largely in response to Rayleigh distillation processes that leaves higher latitude moisture isotopically depleted in heavy isotopes. With this observation, previous studies have interpreted proxy records to reflect variations in the proportion of low vs high latitude moisture.  We found that the isotopic composition of precipitation is dominantly controlled (on a seasonal and annual basis) by the height of condensation, which varies from site to site depending on tropospheric divergence, which causes the upward motion in the atmosphere. On longer, interannual to decadal time scales, variability in condensation height may average out, but research needs to be done to assess how atmospheric behavior affects condensation height on longer time scales.   

We found that paleoclimate proxies from single locations do not capture the atmospheric dynamic responsible for regional scale hydroclimate variability. At the same time, we discovered that there are hemispheric-scale patterns of isotopic change in atmospheric moisture that respond systematically to SST anomalies. These spatial patterns show up in proxies around the Pacific. But, for the isotopic response to be well-correlated with SST forcing requires multiple observations from sites across the Pacific. With a network of proxies it is possible to reconstruct the atmospheric response to SST forcing. This is an important outcome because previous studies used single-site proxy records to suggest that either an El Nino or a La Nina-like state persisted during the Medieval Climate Anomaly and Little Ice Age.  These interpretations differ depending on where the proxy record is from. We found that these disagreements are a consequence of the multiple influences that influence the proxies. But by bringing the records together to produce spatial maps of the isotopic composition of precipitation it is possible to test whether El Nino or La Nina conditions were responsible for hydroclimate extremes in the past.

Robust hydroclimate predictions on decadal time scales are hampered by changing internal variance (e.g. year-to year variations in precipitation) that is sensitive to feedbacks within the climate system. We found that models forced with observed SSTs and sea ice are unable to simulate (predict) the continuation of drought that affected the western US for the past 6 years. Prolonged drought was a manifestation of increased atmospheric variability. Whether internal atmospheric variability will increase as the atmosphere warms is a topic we intend to investigate further. Some existing model results suggest that internal variability should increase as the atmosphere warms in the coming decades. If these results are validated it would mean our ability to provide robust hydrologic predications at decadal time scales will become more difficult.
